_source.contentraw:
Video: New York City now deploying robot police dogs

The New York City Police Department is deploying robotic dogs for use in life-threatening situations, two years after the city previously canceled the move amid public outcry.
â€œDigidog is out of the pound,â€ Mayor Eric Adams said at a press conference Tuesday, the Associated Press reported. â€œDigidog is now part of the toolkit that we are using.â€
The Digidogs, manufactured by Boston Dynamics, would be used in situations like bomb threats, rather than on routine patrols, the New York Times reported.
â€œIf you have a barricaded suspect, if you have someone thatâ€™s inside a building that is armed, instead of sending police in there, you send Digidog in there,â€ Adams said.

https://americanmilitarynews.com/2023/04/video-new-york-city-now-deploying-robot-police-dogs/

Eric Blair).That short novel [Animal Farm] is still sold as anti-Stalinist, but do you really think that is why the CIA bought it and pushed it after the war? No. The book has been promoted so much for so long because it is. . . anti-Revolutionary. The moral of the story seems to be not to bother having a revolution, since it will just makes things worse. Or at least more of the same. The leaders of the revolution are sure to devolve into the same sort of pigs as the old rulers, so why bother? With pigs in charge after the revolution, you will wish you had the men back to run things, since at least they have the capital to get things done. _source.contentraw:
"George Orwell Faked his Death" (2023-04-08) by Miles Mathis
http://mileswmathis.com/orwell.pdf #MilesMathis

In his usual manner, Miles critically examines spooky biography of George Orwell (a.k.a. Eric Blair).

That short novel [Animal Farm] is still sold as anti-Stalinist, but do you really think that is why the CIA bought it and pushed it after the war? No. The book has been promoted so much for so long because it is. . . anti-Revolutionary. The moral of the story seems to be not to bother having a revolution, since it will just makes things worse. Or at least more of the same. The leaders of the revolution are sure to devolve into the same sort of pigs as the old rulers, so why bother? With pigs in charge after the revolution, you will wish you had the men back to run things, since at least they have the capital to get things done. If that isn't the lesson of the book, what is?

Did you know that CIA bought the rights for "Animal Farm" in order to produce 1954 propaganda film?

card.description: The NYPD has brought back robot dogs after abandoning them two years ago following a public outcry
card.title: NYPD re-adopts robot dogs

_source.content: The New York Police Department has brought back Digidog, the four-legged Boston Dynamics robot along with a larger, rounder surveillance bot called K5 ASR, Mayor Eric Adams revealed at a press conference in Times Square on Tuesday.The robot dogs, that inspired an episode of the dystopian TV series Black Mirror, will only be used during â€œhostage situations, bomb threats, counterterrorism situations, things where the best course of action will be to send a Digidog in first before a human being,â€ NYPD chief of department Jeff Maddrey told reporters, calling them a â€œlife saving device.â€The dogs are equipped with cameras and two-way communications, but weaponizing them goes against Boston Dynamicsâ€™ terms of service. The city purchased two for $750,000, but â€œwe used forfeiture money,â€ an NYPD officer reassured reporters.Another new NYPD acquisition, K5 ASR, is a â€œfully autonomous outdoor security robotâ€ used to collect intelligence. Maddrey compared it to a Roomba robot vacuum. Two K5s present at the presser appeared to suffer technical difficulties, standing still for a minute before wheeling away. Finally, a disembodied voice pledged to â€œget stuff done.â€ Neither bot will be equipped with facial recognition technology, NYPD Commissioner Keechant Sewell said, insisting the rollout would be â€œtransparent, consistent, and always done in collaboration with the people that we serve.â€â€œI believe that technology is here; we cannot be afraid of it,â€ Mayor Adams told the audience, explaining that his predecessor, Bill deBlasio, was wrong to retire the robot dog due to public outcry. â€œA few loud people were opposed to it and we took a step back â€“ thatâ€™s not how I operate.â€https://www.rt.com/news/574610-nypd-robot-dogs-adams-dystopia/?utm_source=Newsletter&utm_medium=Email&utm_campaign=Email
_source.contentraw:
The New York Police Department has brought back Digidog, the four-legged Boston Dynamics robot along with a larger, rounder surveillance bot called K5 ASR, Mayor Eric Adams revealed at a press conference in Times Square on Tuesday.

The robot dogs, that inspired an episode of the dystopian TV series Black Mirror, will only be used during â€œhostage situations, bomb threats, counterterrorism situations, things where the best course of action will be to send a Digidog in first before a human being,â€ NYPD chief of department Jeff Maddrey told reporters, calling them a â€œlife saving device.â€

The dogs are equipped with cameras and two-way communications, but weaponizing them goes against Boston Dynamicsâ€™ terms of service. The city purchased two for $750,000, but â€œwe used forfeiture money,â€ an NYPD officer reassured reporters.

Another new NYPD acquisition, K5 ASR, is a â€œfully autonomous outdoor security robotâ€ used to collect intelligence. Maddrey compared it to a Roomba robot vacuum. Two K5s present at the presser appeared to suffer technical difficulties, standing still for a minute before wheeling away. Finally, a disembodied voice pledged to â€œget stuff done.â€

Neither bot will be equipped with facial recognition technology, NYPD Commissioner Keechant Sewell said, insisting the rollout would be â€œtransparent, consistent, and always done in collaboration with the people that we serve.â€

â€œI believe that technology is here; we cannot be afraid of it,â€ Mayor Adams told the audience, explaining that his predecessor, Bill deBlasio, was wrong to retire the robot dog due to public outcry. â€œA few loud people were opposed to it and we took a step back â€“ thatâ€™s not how I operate.â€

And when the rains came back and reservoirs filled, negating their narrative, little attempt was made to save water for the inevitable next drought.

Similarly, in the case of the recent wildfires, Gavin Newsom and his claque in the media blamed changes in the global climate. But it had at least as much to do with green resistance to controlled burns and brush clearance than anything happening on a planetary scale; attempts to impose such fuel controls had been vetoed by Brown and are opposed by the greens and their allies at media outlets like the Los Angeles Times.

Renewable energy may be expensive and unreliable, but state policy enriches the tech oligarchyâ€™s green energy investments, even when their effortsâ€”like the Google-backed Ivanpah solar farmâ€”fail to deÂ­liver affordable, reliable energy. In contemporary California, results matter less than supposed good intentions."

Myers, almost by accident, controls the archives from the Lemberg Center for the Study of Violence, formerly at Brandeis University.
He and his students are working their way through the archives, which detail thousands of race riots that occurred between 1966 and 1973.

NYPD goes high tech; deploys â€˜snitchBOTâ€™ in war on subway thugs
New York City continued its march away from the tried and true methods of policing Tuesday when Mayor Eric Adams (D) announced the return to a previously abandoned pilot program featuring â€œDigi-dogsâ€ and a â€œsnitchBOT.â€
We cannot be afraid of [the technology],â€ Hizzoner said at a Times Square press conference where the technology was demonstrated by members of the New York Police Department. Expected to begin a six-month trial run in June or July alongside a human partner, the K5 Autonomous Security Robot produced by Knightscope boasted an array of surveillance technology.
According to The New York Post, the robot, described by Adams as like a â€œRoombaâ€ and nicknamed â€œsnitchBOT,â€ boasts over a dozen microphones, sonar and lidar sensors, a license plate reader and a 360-degree camera integrated into its 400 pound body. At a cost of $12,250 for the subscription service, the robot with a max speed of 3 mph will monitor the tourist hub and the subway station below to test out its effectiveness.
â€œIf we were not willing to move forward and use technology to properly keep cities safe, then we will not keep up with those who are doing harmful things to hurt New York,â€ Adams said.
â€œA few loud people were opposed to [them previously], and we just took a step back. That is not how I operate or look at whatâ€™s best for the city,â€ he went on.
Expected to cost nearly $750,000 for the pair of robotic â€œdogs,â€ the NYPD made clear that the new tools expected to be used in hostage situations or to investigate bomb threats would not take a dime from the police force budget but rather would be paid for using forfeiture money seized from crimes.

card.title: Robot Police Dog Returns To NYPD Despite Earlier Criticism

_source.content: NYPD Robot Police Dog Returns With Other Robots To New York This SummerApr 11, 2023, 07:28 PM EDTNEW YORK (AP) â€” New York City officials unveiled three new high-tech policing devices Tuesday, including a robotic dog that critics called creepy when it first joined the police pack 2 1/2 years ago.The new devices, which also include a GPS tracker for stolen cars and a cone-shaped security robot, will be rolled out in a manner that is â€œtransparent, consistent and always done in close collaboration with the people we serve,â€ said police Commissioner Keechant Sewell, who joined Mayor Eric Adams and other officials at a Times Square press conference where the security robot and the mechanical canine nicknamed Digidog were displayed.â€œDigidog is out of the pound,â€ said Adams, a Democrat and former police officer. â€œDigidog is now part of the toolkit that we are using.â€The cityâ€™s first robot police dog was leased in 2020 by Adamsâ€™ predecessor, former Mayor Bill de Blasio, but the cityâ€™s contract for the device was cut short after critics derided it as creepy and dystopian.Adams said he wonâ€™t bow to anti-robot dog pressure.â€œA few loud people were opposed to it and we took a step back,â€ the mayor said. â€œThat is not how I operate. I operate on looking at whatâ€™s best for the city.â€Adams said the remote-controlled, 70-pound (32-kilogram) Digidog will be deployed in risky situations like hostage standoffs starting this summer.â€œIf you have a barricaded suspect, if you have someone thatâ€™s inside a building that is armed, instead of sending police in there, you send Digidog in there,â€ he said. â€œSo these are smart ways of using good technologies.â€The tracking system called StarChase will allow police to launch a GPS tag that will attach itself to a stolen car so that officers can track the vehicleâ€™s location. The New York Police Departmentâ€™s pilot program for using the system will last 90 days, officials said.The Autonomous Security Robot, which Adams compared to a Roomba, will be deployed inside the Times Square subway station in a seven-month pilot program starting this summer, police officials said.The device, used in shopping centers and other locations for several years, will at first be joined by a human partner, police said.Civil libertarians and police reform advocates questioned the need for the high-tech devices.â€œThis latest announcement is just the most recent example of how Mayor Adams allows unmitigated overspending of the NYPDâ€™s massively bloated budget,â€ said Ileana Mendez-Penate, program director of Communities United for Police Reform. â€œThe NYPD is buying robot dogs and other fancy tech while New Yorkers canâ€™t access food stamps because city agencies are short-staffed, and New Yorkers are getting evicted because they canâ€™t access their right to counsel.â€Albert Fox Cahn, executive director of the Surveillance Technology Oversight Project, said: â€œThe NYPD is turning bad science fiction into terrible policing. New York deserves real safety, not a knockoff RoboCop.â€https://www.huffpost.com/entry/nypd-robots-dog_n_6435e276e4b0fc8aefe02174https://twitter.com/NYCMayor/status/1645810959439519745

NYPD Robot Police Dog Returns With Other Robots To New York This Summer

Apr 11, 2023, 07:28 PM EDT

NEW YORK (AP) â€” New York City officials unveiled three new high-tech policing devices Tuesday, including a robotic dog that critics called creepy when it first joined the police pack 2 1/2 years ago.

The new devices, which also include a GPS tracker for stolen cars and a cone-shaped security robot, will be rolled out in a manner that is â€œtransparent, consistent and always done in close collaboration with the people we serve,â€ said police Commissioner Keechant Sewell, who joined Mayor Eric Adams and other officials at a Times Square press conference where the security robot and the mechanical canine nicknamed Digidog were displayed.

â€œDigidog is out of the pound,â€ said Adams, a Democrat and former police officer. â€œDigidog is now part of the toolkit that we are using.â€

The cityâ€™s first robot police dog was leased in 2020 by Adamsâ€™ predecessor, former Mayor Bill de Blasio, but the cityâ€™s contract for the device was cut short after critics derided it as creepy and dystopian.

Adams said he wonâ€™t bow to anti-robot dog pressure.

â€œA few loud people were opposed to it and we took a step back,â€ the mayor said. â€œThat is not how I operate. I operate on looking at whatâ€™s best for the city.â€

Adams said the remote-controlled, 70-pound (32-kilogram) Digidog will be deployed in risky situations like hostage standoffs starting this summer.

â€œIf you have a barricaded suspect, if you have someone thatâ€™s inside a building that is armed, instead of sending police in there, you send Digidog in there,â€ he said. â€œSo these are smart ways of using good technologies.â€

The tracking system called StarChase will allow police to launch a GPS tag that will attach itself to a stolen car so that officers can track the vehicleâ€™s location. The New York Police Departmentâ€™s pilot program for using the system will last 90 days, officials said.

The Autonomous Security Robot, which Adams compared to a Roomba, will be deployed inside the Times Square subway station in a seven-month pilot program starting this summer, police officials said.

The device, used in shopping centers and other locations for several years, will at first be joined by a human partner, police said.

Civil libertarians and police reform advocates questioned the need for the high-tech devices.

â€œThis latest announcement is just the most recent example of how Mayor Adams allows unmitigated overspending of the NYPDâ€™s massively bloated budget,â€ said Ileana Mendez-Penate, program director of Communities United for Police Reform. â€œThe NYPD is buying robot dogs and other fancy tech while New Yorkers canâ€™t access food stamps because city agencies are short-staffed, and New Yorkers are getting evicted because they canâ€™t access their right to counsel.â€

Albert Fox Cahn, executive director of the Surveillance Technology Oversight Project, said: â€œThe NYPD is turning bad science fiction into terrible policing. New York deserves real safety, not a knockoff RoboCop.â€

card.description: Commentary Lock Donald Trump up, or donâ€™t lock him up, but donâ€™t tell me that â€œno one is ...
card.title: No One Is Above the Law? Give Me a Break

_source.content: Lock Donald Trump up (if proven to have committed a crime), or donâ€™t lock him up, but donâ€™t tell me that â€œno one is above the law.â€ Itâ€™s one of the most ludicrous fantasies peddled by the left.Plenty of people are â€œabove the law.â€ James Clapper, who lied under oath to Congress about spying on the American people, is above the law. John Brennan, who lied about a domestic spying operation on Senate staffers, is above the law. Unlike Trump adviser Peter Navarro, Obamaâ€™s Attorney General Eric Holder was never going to be handcuffed and thrown in prison for ignoring a congressional subpoena. He is above the law.Trumpâ€™s 2016 opponent, Hillary Clinton, is also above the law. The then-secretary of state set up a private server in her home to circumvent transparency surrounding her slush fund foundation. She sent 110 emails containing marked classified information, and 36 of those emails contained secret information. Eight of the email chains contained â€œtop secretâ€ information. Every one of those instances was a potential felony punishable with up to 10 years in prison.We learned all of this from James Comey, then FBI director, who noted that Clinton had been â€œextremely carelessâ€ in conducting her business. Comey didnâ€™t recommend charges because, he claimed, the state couldnâ€™t prove Clintonâ€™s intentâ€”even though â€œgross negligence,â€ not intent, was the only standard he needed. Gross negligence and extreme carelessness are synonyms. Comey concocted a new standard to protect Clinton because she is above the law.When Hillaryâ€™s husband, also above the law, perjured himself under oath, Democrats argued that puritanical conservatives were only pursuing Bill because of some trumped-up charge over â€œsex.â€ Using that logic, Trumpâ€™s campaign finance charges related to Stormy Danielsâ€™ â€œhush moneyâ€ are also about sex. This is different because Trump is the boogeyman, and everyone knows heâ€™s guilty of something. The important thing is getting that mug shot.Donâ€™t worry, though; former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi says, â€œEveryone has the right to a trial to prove innocence.â€ By â€œeveryone,â€ she means Republicans. And if you think this authoritarian formulation is an accident, you havenâ€™t been paying attention. When Democrats were smearing Brett Kavanaugh as a (gang) rapist a few years back, Sen. Mazie Hirono was asked whether the then-nominee deserved the â€œsame presumption of innocence as anyone else in America?â€ After all, this wasnâ€™t about any judicial disagreement but about alleged criminal behavior. The Hawaii senator responded, â€œI put his denial in the context of everything that I know about him in terms of how he approaches his cases.â€In other words, if youâ€™re a conservative, your politics are evil; and if your politics are evil, youâ€™re probably evil. I imagine that was the rationalization used by Kamala Harris when reading obvious fabrications about Kavanaugh into the Congressional Record. It is likely the rationalization of Lois Lerner or Merrick Garlandâ€”both above the lawâ€”when they weaponized government agencies against political opponents. It is almost surely the rationalization of Manhattan District Attorney Alvin Bragg. This is what justifies the contemporary leftâ€™s increasing comfort with deploying the state to punish and destroy political enemies. For many progressives, the legal system isnâ€™t merely a tool for criminal justice (if that) but a way to exact poetic political justice.Despite there being perfectly sound political arguments against Trump, we have been on a hysterical journey that has taken us from accusing Trump of being a seditious actor working on the orders of an antagonistic foreign governmentâ€”the most successful conspiracy theory ever spun in American politicsâ€”to indicting him on some rickety seven-year-old campaign finance violation charge. Giving a porn star â€œhush moneyâ€ is an immorality, not an illegality. Are DAs now going to be in the business of indicting political opponents who put $130,000 on the wrong side of the ledger during a race that cost hundreds of millions of dollars? I look forward to this kind of justice being meted out equallyâ€¦.By David HarsanyiApril 7, 2023Commentaryhttps://www.theepochtimes.com/no-one-is-above-the-law-give-me-a-break_5180242.html?utm_source=share-btn-copylink

Lock Donald Trump up (if proven to have committed a crime), or donâ€™t lock him up, but donâ€™t tell me that â€œno one is above the law.â€ Itâ€™s one of the most ludicrous fantasies peddled by the left.
Plenty of people are â€œabove the law.â€ James Clapper, who lied under oath to Congress about spying on the American people, is above the law. John Brennan, who lied about a domestic spying operation on Senate staffers, is above the law. Unlike Trump adviser Peter Navarro, Obamaâ€™s Attorney General Eric Holder was never going to be handcuffed and thrown in prison for ignoring a congressional subpoena. He is above the law.

Trumpâ€™s 2016 opponent, Hillary Clinton, is also above the law. The then-secretary of state set up a private server in her home to circumvent transparency surrounding her slush fund foundation. She sent 110 emails containing marked classified information, and 36 of those emails contained secret information. Eight of the email chains contained â€œtop secretâ€ information. Every one of those instances was a potential felony punishable with up to 10 years in prison.

We learned all of this from James Comey, then FBI director, who noted that Clinton had been â€œextremely carelessâ€ in conducting her business. Comey didnâ€™t recommend charges because, he claimed, the state couldnâ€™t prove Clintonâ€™s intentâ€”even though â€œgross negligence,â€ not intent, was the only standard he needed. Gross negligence and extreme carelessness are synonyms. Comey concocted a new standard to protect Clinton because she is above the law.

When Hillaryâ€™s husband, also above the law, perjured himself under oath, Democrats argued that puritanical conservatives were only pursuing Bill because of some trumped-up charge over â€œsex.â€ Using that logic, Trumpâ€™s campaign finance charges related to Stormy Danielsâ€™ â€œhush moneyâ€ are also about sex. This is different because Trump is the boogeyman, and everyone knows heâ€™s guilty of something. The important thing is getting that mug shot.

Donâ€™t worry, though; former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi says, â€œEveryone has the right to a trial to prove innocence.â€ By â€œeveryone,â€ she means Republicans. And if you think this authoritarian formulation is an accident, you havenâ€™t been paying attention. When Democrats were smearing Brett Kavanaugh as a (gang) rapist a few years back, Sen. Mazie Hirono was asked whether the then-nominee deserved the â€œsame presumption of innocence as anyone else in America?â€ After all, this wasnâ€™t about any judicial disagreement but about alleged criminal behavior. The Hawaii senator responded, â€œI put his denial in the context of everything that I know about him in terms of how he approaches his cases.â€

In other words, if youâ€™re a conservative, your politics are evil; and if your politics are evil, youâ€™re probably evil. I imagine that was the rationalization used by Kamala Harris when reading obvious fabrications about Kavanaugh into the Congressional Record. It is likely the rationalization of Lois Lerner or Merrick Garlandâ€”both above the lawâ€”when they weaponized government agencies against political opponents.
